docs.lead_paragraph: Looking up from her morning exertions on a stationary bicycle, Rena Kahn gave the famous young woman on the television screen a cool, but not unsympathetic, appraisal. ''She seems like she's really in control, like they prepped her really well,'' said Ms. Kahn, nodding toward the videotaped image of Monica S. Lewinsky playing on the set hanging above her exercise machine. ''But whoever does her hair, well, I don't know,'' she said. ''And the poor thing has really ballooned up.''

headline.main: Some Compassion for Lewinsky, But Fleeting Interest by Viewers

docs.abstract: New Yorkers at fitness center pause on exercise machines to watch Monica Lewinsky's testimony to Senate impeachment trial of Pres Clinton; express some compassion, though only fleeting interest, as they appraise Lewinsky's appearance and demeanor; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Looking up from her morning exertions on a stationary bicycle, Rena Kahn gave the famous young woman on the television screen a cool, but not unsympathetic, appraisal.    ''She seems like she's really in control, like they prepped her really well,''...

docs.lead_paragraph: IT was after midnight on a frigid Friday night. Slot machines pinged and binged inside Caesar's, Bally's, the Showboat, the Tropicana and a dozen more casinos. Thousands of patrons were sending their quarters and dollars -- with few exceptions -- into the deep, deep pockets of the rich. Near the northern end of the casino strip, under a pier where the boardwalk meets the Taj Mahal, another kind of gamble was playing out.

headline.main: Young and Homeless; Lured by Atlantic City's Riches, They End Up in the Underbelly

docs.abstract: There were 13,000 homeless people under age of 21 in 1993, and number has risen since then; Atlantic City has significant population of local homeless youth, and it also attracts runaways from around country, partly because of glitter and lights of casinos, and aura of easy money; most end up trading sex for few dollars or place to live, or dealing drugs, or committing more serious crimes; outreach workers at Covenant House describe their frustrating efforts to help these drifting teens; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WEB sites for would-be, armchair and actual travelers are proliferating faster than you can say ''dotcom,'' with so many links that it's easy to lose your way. Following are 44 useful, informative or intriguing sites that can help you find or reach your destination.

docs.lead_paragraph: IT was spring when J. Geraldine Jackson first began to feel the world closing in on her. It seemed as if she were living in a cave inside her mind. She slept countless hours and lost her job. Her heart raced. Sometimes her left leg went numb. Her favorite television show, ''The Equalizer,'' a dark drama about crime in Manhattan, no longer held its allure. Noise -- especially laughter -- made her want to fight. It was a little smart talk from her sister that finally set her off. She pummeled her sister with her fists, grabbed a pocketbook and a change of clothes, and fled the housing project in the Bronx where she lived with her mother. She landed in a homeless shelter.

headline.main: The Nation; Seeing a Link Between Depression and Homelessness

docs.abstract: Mental health experts are discovering that depression and manic-depression, with wild mood swings, are significant cause of homelessness and say aggressive efforts to identify people with disorders could significantly reduce population of homeless shelters; struggle of J Geraldine Jackson, former resident of New York City homeless shelter, to conquer manic-depression discussed; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The State Health Benefits Plan continued to provide benefits last year for people who were no longer eligible, including 17 people who were dead, according to a state audit. The audit suggested that thousands of people enrolled in the plan may not be eligible, officials said yesterday.

headline.main: Ex-Employees Remain On State Health Plan

docs.abstract: State audit finds that New Jersey Health Benefits Plan continued to provide benefits last year for people who were no longer eligible, including 17 people who were dead (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Kathy Passanisi stood before more than 100 managers at Bausch & Lomb headquarters here and asked one what he would say if his son came home with spiked green hair and a cluster of earrings. ''You're starting to look more like your mother,'' came the reply.

headline.main: Serious Talk About Funny Business; So Many Executives, So Few Light Bulbs

docs.abstract: Growing number companies that are often viewed as staid businesses--banks, telephone and computer companies--are hiring 'humor consultants' to invigorate executives stunned by increasing demands and rapidly changing technology; consultants are not hired just to entertain; their goal is to teach executives that laughter does wonders in communicating with employees, and perhaps it will help overcome their fear of the boss; techniques used by consultant Kathy Passanisi described; photos; cartoons (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The state Dental Society has sued the Pataki administration over the rate at which dentists are reimbursed for treating low-income New Yorkers under the Medicaid system. The suit, which was filed on Tuesday in Federal District Court in Albany, contends that Medicaid dental rates have not appreciably increased for three decades in New York and, as a result, most dentists no longer treat Medicaid-covered patients.

headline.main: Dentists Sue the State Over Medicaid Payments

docs.lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about the indictments of 65 people on charges of defrauding health insurers in New Jersey quoted incorrectly from Elaugh Butler, one of the 65. She did not say that she had called for treatment from a psychologist and never received it, or that she had cashed checks the psychologist had sent her; she was describing experiences of other people who were being investigated.
docs.abstract: Correction of quote contained in Feb 3 article on health insurance fraud case in New Jersey

docs.lead_paragraph: After two years of cuts in government aid, a sharp increase in uninsured patients and the growing dominance of managed care, hospitals in the New York region are bracing for what many people believe will be one of the most difficult fiscal years ever. And with recent proposals from Albany and the White House that would squeeze hundreds of millions of dollars more from local medical centers, hospital executives and many health care experts are predicting significant budget cuts and warning of possible hospital closings and an erosion in patient care.

headline.main: As Aid Is Cut, Hospitals Prepare for a Tough Year

docs.abstract: Hospitals in New York region, after two years of cuts in government aid, sharp increase in uninsured patients and growing dominance of managed care, are bracing for what many people believe will be one of most difficult fiscal years ever; with recent proposals from Albany and White House that would squeeze hundreds of millions of dollars more from local medical centers, hospital execs and many health care experts are predicting significant budget cuts and warning of possible hospital closings and an erosion of patient care; most likely to be hit hard are New York City's public hospitals and others that serve the poor and are most dependent on income from government health insurance programs, Medicaid and Medicare (M)
docs.snippet: After two years of cuts in government aid, a sharp increase in uninsured patients and the growing dominance of managed care, hospitals in the New York region are bracing for what many people believe will be one of the most difficult fiscal years...

docs.lead_paragraph: The health plan managers that Nassau County officials contended had overcharged the county have agreed to pay $16 million in exchange for the county's agreement not to sue the company, officials said today. The accord between the county and Benefit Plan Administrators was announced before the County Legislature's Rules Committee met in special session to hear testimony on who was responsible for up to $50 million in unexpected costs for the health plan, costs that the county has said contributed to a deficit in last fiscal year's budget that could exceed $100 million.

headline.main: Nassau Agrees To Skip Suits On Insurance After Payment

docs.abstract: Benefit Plan Administrators, which allegedly overcharged Nassau County on employee health plan, agrees to pay county $16 million and up to $150,000 toward cost of legislative probe of case in return for county's agreement not to sue company; County Legislature's Rules Committee meets in special spession to probe up to $50 million in unexpected health plan costs; William M Blake, whose insurance agency underwote deal, fails to appear; reportedly is hospitalized (M)
